subject: Productivity
title: The Tyranny of the Trivial
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: The Tyranny of the Trivial.

hook.text: Cyril Northcote Parkinson noticed that committees spend more time on bike sheds than nuclear reactors.

buildup.text: Parkinson's Law of Triviality says people give disproportionate weight to trivial issues because they're easy to grasp.

discovery.text: Complex decisions feel overwhelming. Simple ones feel controllable. So meetings devolve into debating font colors.

twist.text: This isn't stupidity. It's a cognitive bias. The brain prefers problems it can solve over ones it can't easily grasp.

climax.text: Strategic thinkers deliberately allocate decision time proportional to decision impact, not decision ease.

punchline.text: Don't spend big time on small decisions.

quiz.question: What does Parkinson's Law of Triviality describe?
options: People spend more time on trivial issues than complex important ones
Important decisions always take the most time
